1) Essential purchase

Rage against the alien machine
Alien Rage: Unlimited from CI games, the development house responsible for the Sniper: Ghost Warrior series, is a game few would have played which explains the reason it turned up in one of the bundle deals recently. Alien Rage's chance of success, while probably never really high to begin with was only further diminished after professional critics tore the game to shreds - which is a terrible shame because underneath all the Halo/Gears of War (insert any other shooter featuring marines in space) similarities is a terribly old-school on-the-rails corridor shooter that should be appreciated more by gamers who grew up playing the original DOOM and Wolfenstein back in the early nineties.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=301430217
Set upon a massive asteroid that has become home to both humans and an alien species who are seemingly able to co-exist jointly mining the rock for the highly efficient energy source known as Prometheum until this shaky alliance is turned on its head when all the human miners are systematically eradicated by the alien hoard. With all operations further suspended your task is to get into the mining facility and destroy it using what ever force necessary.

The game will have you battling through 14 intense (and I say intense) levels because Alien Rage was designed to be difficult. With difficulty settings starting at challenging some might find it a tad too difficult during the initial levels and I have to agree with some of the more professional reviewers that the game does suffer from some severe difficulty spikes that I could well see a person leaving the game due to frustration. Things do bed down a bit once you start unlocking perks which can then be applied to your character such as 50% less damage from projectiles (which I found incredibly handy because at the start of the game any alien shooting projectile damage towards my character would instantly result in his death). The game does use a checkpoint system to save the game and thankfully they are not used sparingly so as difficult as the game can get sometimes the player should be able to make steady progress. Alien Rage features a leaderboard and uses score modifiers so the more headshots and destructible environmental damage you cause the higher your score.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=288804235
Alien Rage was developed using the trusty Unreal Engine 3 and it shows in some of the games more unique underground mining settings. While plenty of reviewers were quick to point out that the player runs through an endless labyrinthine of generic levels, I have to disagree. Yes while some level design is often repeated throughout the 14 scenarios presented I found some of the levels particularly striking as I stood still for a few seconds just to take in the sights and sounds. Alien Rage can really be quite the looker for the most part and if you don't believe me just run on over and take a squizz at the screenshots I have posted for the game.

If I do have some slight gripes it's that of all the weapons presented I found only a handful of them were really effective which forced me to discard experimenting with various weapons early on in game because most of what is needed to see yourself safely execute this mission is presented from the get-go. The games boss battles are also a source of frustration. They are long and tedious fights of attrition and often you will find you have run out of ammo which results in you having to fall back on your weaker arsenol such as your pistol - which while still effective - only end up dragging the boss fights on longer than need be because of the smaller damage they do. Most bosses go through two or more phases during a fight which is is where the frustrating aspect rears its ugly head because should you die during the bosses second or third phase you are doomed to repeat everything from the beginning. One particular boss fight near the end of the game really had me on the verge of a rage-fit but thankfully a step away from the game for a while was all that was needed.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=297264842
Challenging and sometimes incredibly frustrating - Alien Rage is not going to appeal to everyone but if you looking for a solid run and gun shooter that refuses to hold your hand then Alien Rage may just be the game for you. Despite its failings I still ended up really enjoying my time with the game which is a lot more than I can say for other recently released AAA titles in this genre. If you are not prepared to pay the full price of $19.99 ( I got the game in a bundle deal for less that $4) then I can heartily recommend you pick it up during a Steam sale.

reviewText:
A fun but flawed first person shooter.  AI has shown the capability to flank however the appearance of rushing the player is apparent.  Aliens do have the ability to melee as well as stasis the player so I won't hold AI rushing against the game.  Aliens can and do flank though they are not the brightest bulbs and will get themselves killed rather easily when isolated.   Boss fights are numerous but straight forward not showing much imagination.

The game has three difficulty modes each increasing in challenge.  I started with the middle difficulty but initially my life lasted as long as a Gastrotrich, so normal it was as my mood was for limiting restarts as much as possible given the game's propensity to kill you.

Story elements in the form of recordings are spread around the levels but I only found one third of the content. Whether I missed their obvious placement by chance or because they were hidden is unknown though the story can be ignored from the small portion I heard.  Bonus mini pyramids are also strewn about, three per level but again I never completed a set.  The pyramids add to your score as Alien Rage awards points during game-play and includes leader-boards as well.

Secondary ammo is also strewn about.  They look like suitcases so they aren't hard to miss although initially I wasn't sure what they were which brings us to the weapons.  An important part of any shooter.   The weapons are imaginative.  You get to carry only two plus a revolver.  There is a high reliance on secondary fire in order to implement much needed crowd control.  Primary ammo is picked up through gun pick ups as a dropped gun retains it's ammo or by walking over the same gun as you possess.   Weapons in the game consist of both alien and human.  Human weapons consist of differing semi automatic rifles, a sniper rifle, mentioned revolver, shotgun and rocket launcher.  Sounds and reads standard however each weapon has an important secondary fire mode as mentioned.

The rocket launcher, for example, when equipped will affect your sprinting ability and to use or un-equip the launcher the full animation must be run through making the weapon a bit strategic and difficult to use, a welcome feature considering the weapon's ability to quickly change the battlefield.  Which reminds me of enemy hit-boxes which I found to be well implemented.  I can remember shooting a rocket through enemy legs and cursing myself for lack of careful aiming.

The alien arsenal consists of energy weapons and is somewhat more limited.  No rocket launcher for example but the weapons are fun to use.  The alien rifle for instance has no reloads, however the weapon will overheat, again ensuring the player makes strategic use of the weapon.  The alien shotgun is very cool and very powerful, the cool anti gravity  secondary fire helps immensely.  To summarize the S in FPS, the shooting is exceptional, it's explosive and fun.

Some reviewers have panned the levels as being too generic.  So what.  The game looks and sounds great.  You feel Alien Rage, your feel of the game, both visual and auditory is significant.  Many of the levels have nice set pieces and it's great to see a publisher like City Interactive enable their development team to build a game with strong immersive environmental elements.  Great explosions not only permeate the combat but play a central role.  Graphically the game is exceptional though performance will vary but not enough to detract from the game.

Lastly I will address the utter disaster that is the Alien Rage checkpoint system.   Wait, it is not a system.  Systems by definition imply some sort of systematic routine.  No, the check-pointing, no, make that the checkpoint restart logic in Alien Rage is not just buggy.   I've come to the conclusion that it is unfinished.  There is no other reason for checkpoint restarts missing assets, many of which will prevent you from continuing the game.  Explosives for blowing apart levels to continue, needed secondary ammunition for combat , platforms not reset so you're left looking like a shopper waiting for a mall elevator.

I've found that after each death, instead of using the checkpoint continue, I had to exit to the main menu and continue from there.  It is beyond my wildest imagination how the developers obviously knowing that there checkpoint restart system was broken could not of just rewired their checkpoint code to use the continuation logic from the main menu.  From the continue on the main menu the game loaded correctly every time.  As the game loads very fast,  circumventing the intended method for checkpoint restarts is not a significant issue.

If you enjoy a good FPS then Alien Rage presents itself as a very challenging fun FPS that will satisfy most any FPS urge.

reviewText:
i want to start by saying that the overall negative reviews of this game have been heavily unfair and undeserved - this is a thoroughly decent fps title that promises nothing more than good shooting fun, and on that front it delivers.

this quick review is based on about 1 hr of gameplay, but i feel that i have seen enough to give a proper evaluation. the game is thin on story or character development, and is more of a throwback to the old days of shooters, when u needed very little reason to shoot other than the fact that aliens r on the receiving end of it. the graphics is not groundbreaking but certainly decent, as the unreal engine does a good job with a colourful design (more so than most unreal engine games). the sounds is decent too, but the highlight for me is the gameplay, which is fast and despite the flaws, extremely entertaining and more than worth the excursion.

speaking of flaws, it should be noted that there r occasional moments which detract from the otherwise excellent action - the AI is not the best in the world, with enemies sometimes seemingly frozen for moments, and much of the difficulty if delivered through otherwise very tough and accurate enemies. on one occasion, i found limbs of enemies blown up floating in the air. however, such instances r few and far in between, and dont distract from the otherwise excellent fps action. you don't need a top-tier machine to run the game at its finest (i ran it on a fairly modest laptop config).

for any fps fan, this game is very easy for me to recommend, specially when on a sale (i bought it at 80% off at gmg), and looking at the level list i have ahead of me, the campaign does seem to be of a decent length (at least by current fps campaign standards). my major gripe is with multiplayer tho, the mode seems more than serviceable, but a lack of gamers online here is of concern, altho to b honest, i would blame the negative reviews this game has received so far on this. and its a shame, for the fps action is solid, the guns come it both the human and alien variety and r fun to play around with. the highlight for me so far was one moment when i tore a minigun off the rails, and went on a rampage, and while doing so, the protagonist starting roaring........brilliant touch.

buy this game!! developers who deliver fun quality action in a solid package for so cheap deserve to be supported. well done, ci games!

You should definitely pick up the demo and see for yourself, but I enjoyed it alot and now that it has been pretty much patched it's pretty good.

I play it on normal and I had my moments when I literally wanted to rip my guts out because of the sometimes really, REALLY unfair challenges and punishing difficulty. Alien Rage Unlimited isn't a bad game per se, but it's not a good one either. The description makes it look and sound like a Bulletstorm clone. Bulletstorm is awesome, but this one... this one is not. There's a variety of moves you can pull off which result in you earning points. Make a headshot and you'll earn a certain amount of points, destroy enemies using explosions and it'll earn you points as well. Well, you get the picture, right ? There aren't enough moves to keep you going so after a while it becomes tiresome and the joy of earning points diminishes.

The levels and enemies are fairly detailed and the whole game looks pretty good, especially considering the price they ask for it.

Thankfully, it's also a pretty short game. Finishing it will take you about 6 hours overall. More than enough if you ever decide to give this a try. There are so many difficulty spikes that it becomes more frustrating than fun halfway through the game. I don't know who programmed this AI but it's terribly unbalanced.

And even though it's not the best game out there it definitely had some good moments. I just wish there were more of those... More Bulletstorm, less Alien Rage please.

reviewText:
First Person Shooter throwback!
Alien Rage - Unlimited is an action-packed fast-paced FPS. This game went under the radar for me.I bought it recently, and I’m very glad I did.

Despite the corny jokes, thin story and character development, Alien Rage represents a throwback to the roots of first person shooters. It stands on its own and proves that you don’t need a great plot to justify the fact that you’re just shooting aliens in the face.

That said, the story intrigued me at first. In a time where Earth is facing an energy and financial crysis, humankind discovers a resource called Promethium, which is able to produce enormous amounts of energy. Shortly after settling down and beginning mining operations, an alien race appears. Despite the initial cooperation between the two, things go south real fast. Thus, it is your job to make sure that the enemy can’t get their hands on this precious resource. What better way is there to do that than killing and blowing up everything in that forsaken asteroid?

The game is ridiculously hard on maximum difficulty, so only consider playing on it if you’re a masochist or a godlike player. I played on  Hard setting until the very last boss. There I changed to Normal because it was too frustrating after dying many times.

Pros:10 unique weapons, each with two different fire modes
Each weapon feels authenthic and satisfying to use
Unlockable perks, such as more ammunition and more weapon damage
Decent enemy variety
Memorable and challenging boss fights
Visually the game still looks pretty good (it uses Unreal Engine 3)
Rewards exploration with tokens that grant you points and audio logs, which reveal the events before the game
Skill and accuracy is rewarded with more points
Neutral:Regenerating health. This might appeal to some people, while to others it might be a big negative.
It is an on-rails shooter with a very linear campaign
Cons:Somewhat short, took me around 6 hours to beat it
Online multiplayer is dead
The story started out nicely, but quickly fell apart and became bland
Overall experience:

Alien Rage - Unlimited is an hectic and frantic shooter, and it was refreshing. It is one of those games that stands out in an era where most FPS take place in a modern or near future setting. The gunplay is extremely satisfying and you’re able to pick between sticking with human or alien weapons. Despite the fact that what you mostly do is gun down aliens, there are some memorable moments, such as boss fights and when your character starts screaming while you’re unloading a minigun clip. I highly recommend Alien Rage to any fans of first person shooters. It is well worth your time!

Rating:

I’d rate Alien Rage - Unlimited a solid 8/10.

reviewText:
Waste of my time, really. Sure, the game looks great, and feels great, at times- but with only one type of environment, this gets repetitive quite fast. The score feature is kinda neat, albeit unneeded. I can look past the linear almost nonexistant story, that's not what I got the game for. I got the game for a solid shooter. I did not get a solid shooter.

The game suffers from poor movement mechanics than end up feeling more clunky as time goes on. Your crosshair bobs up and down and sways as you move- you could argue it adds realism, but for an unrealistic game that is trying to be an arcade/arena shooter? Not needed- only frustrating. You apparently also cannot run while shooting, and jumping needs more of an impulse- things even at hip height that you should be able to jump over, you cannot. You'd think this game would have some kind of cover system, but it does not- you can only hide behind things and hope that cheap explosives or minigun shells won't noclip it. (This happens quite a bit, btw.)

The AI is horrible and half the time they are only standing completely still firing shots at you. Enemies only really feel challenging when they are using an overpowered weapon. The game only saves during checkpoints- which wouldn't be so bad if there were more of them, but instead they should 2 or 3 huge encouters at you before each one.

Bosses soak up damage like a sponge and fire instagib shots at you rapidly, over and over. But otherwise have pretty boring moves or mechanics- boss fights basically become a game of cover and shoot, for the next 5 minutes. It's not hard, its just annoying. And dying to one shot because you weren't 100% covered, and having to replay the last boring 5 minutes, feels like a collasal waste of time.

There is nothing really good to say about the game, other than it looks really good. It's challenging, but not in the right ways. The mechanics are boring. The AI is boring. The story is not interesting. I much rather play through the original Unreal, Half Life, or Doom, or Quake... than have to play this game again. I'm an old shooter vet. I've seen other shooter vets promote this game. I guess the only difference between me and them is... I'm able to call a duck a duck.

reviewText:
To keep it simple, this is a fun game. I found a keycode for it online super cheap and figured it'd be worth a try. Can't get too burnt when it's only $5 right? Having played the Xbox 360 version, I can say this is definitely an improvement in many ways. For starters, the PC version runs significantly smoother with even better graphics and it even has online multiplayer functionality. Steam only has me logged in at around half an hour of play time on the PC version but I've played the game quite a bit on Xbox.

Basically the game is an homage to old-school shooters but with fancy new graphics and such. If you've played Doom or Quake, you've played this game already (not that that's a bad thing by any means.) It's a simplistic FPS title with a nice variety in guns and some halfway-decent AI, but linear in its narrative. Don't expect anything spectacular, however. As far as gameplay goes it's pretty standard fare, but for a budget shooter it's presented nicely. Firefights can be fun and engaging and the game has a points system very similar to Bulletstorm where different types of kills will net you a variety of points/combos/etc.

Sound and level design are okay-- again, don't expect AAA quality. Mostly just trudging through hallways, picking up ammo, dispatching enemies, etc. Boss fights were slightly more interesting. Voice acting is just awful but it makes the game really funny.

Haven't played much multiplayer, don't think there's a big fanbase for the game right now (and it's a little over a year old.)

If you can take this game for a little more than face value and appreciate it despite its shortcomings, you have at least a halfway decent FPS.

8/10

reviewText:
THE GOOD

-Shooting feels great. The pistol, in particular, is awesome and a huge amount of fun to use.
-OK weapon variety
-You can move quickly

THE BAD

-Entirely linear. There are a few times when it opens up into slightly larger rooms but they are still just rooms with one entrance and one exit.

-Monotonous visual design, which makes it even more boring. The visual design in a game can sometimes alleviate the boredom brought on by linearity, but here every level looks the same, which makes it worse.

-Frequent bad checkpointing. The game itself isn't as hard as it's cracked up to be. I played it on the easiest difficulty because I had heard the hype about how hard it is, and that was a mistake. I didn't die that much. Most bosses I didn't die at all. (The game wasn't compelling enough for me to give it another playthrough on a higher difficulty.) However, when I did die, I usually re-spawned right back into the middle of a firefight and immediately died again before I was able to get to cover. C'mon developers, checkpoint placing is a really basic thing, how did you screw it up?

-There just isn't enough playstyle variety to make the Bulletstorm-esque style points system interesting. You can get headshots, explosion kills, and kill streaks. That's it. If you're going to make a style points system in your game you have to at least give you more than two basic combat methods.

-Terrible performance. I have an i5-3470, GTX 970, 16GB ram, and a 144Hz monitor. On medium/high settings I can sometimes get 144 FPS solid, but at other times it tanks down to 40 FPS for no apparent reason. Even locked 144 FPS or locked 60 FPS feels pretty bad and stuttery, so it seems like the game has wildly erratic frame times. Games should feel smooth at 60+ FPS and when they don't that's because the game engine blows at regulating frame time varience, which is pretty basic stuff for any competent developer.

Overall it's just got too many problems to recommend. If not for the performance issues, I would recommend it as a sub-$5 buy for FPS fans as it's a decent enough mindless romp, but the performance problems are unpleasant enough to put it solidly in the don't buy" category."

Alien Rage is a reasonably entertaining FPS whose good moments are unfortunately spoiled by some questionable design decisions. This is a shame, because it was close to being a surprise hit.

The shooting feels great and there's some variety in weapons, but you're restricted tactically by the 3 weapon carry limit. The game has regenerating health, which I've never liked. However, the enemy AI is VERY aggressive, they don't just sit back and let you hide behind a crate until back on full health, so its not as bad as some other games. Level design is very linear, and full of corridors blocked off by tiny objects that you're not allowed to jump over.

The story actually has some depth. You're the standard tough guy space marine sent into a mineral processing facility that is under attack by hordes of aliens. But I got the feeling that the aliens might not be the ones who started the conflict and I was interested to find out more. Unfortunately, most of the back story is told through collectable audio logs, and I missed a few of them so I couldn't fully understand what happened. Its also one of those games where friendlies talk over comms while you're in combat. Note to games industry: if I'm busy trying to stay alive, I'M NOT LISTENING TO THIS. Let me secure the area before you talk to me.

Just know that before I say anything, the last boss fight in this game completely ruins the entire game. It is without question the worst final boss fight I have ever had the misfortune of playing. I had previously said the last boss in Cavestory+ was the worst but this one beats that by infinity.

Edit: it wasn't even the last boss but the boss right before last lol. I used to be able to proudly say that since I've been playing PC games since around 1997, I have not ever once in my life had to download a trainer for a game to cheat until now, and I have played them all. Not literally of course, but I have played a countless amount of games. Yes the next to last boss is that horrible. And after I beat him, I just was so tired of this headache of a game that I didn't bother turning the trainer off and finished the last boss and the game with it on. I could tell that the last boss was just as horrible as the one before it.

This game uses the same control feel and engine as the game Bulletstorm. Even the main assault rifle is the same and the main voice actor is the same guy from that game as well. The main difference between the two games is that this game is very sub-par and Bulletstorm is a good game and a cult favorite.

Unless you have some good twitch style gaming skills you will be doing parts over and over again. I am a pretty solid oldschool twitch gamer and I was redoing parts a lot. This is without question the hardest FPS I have ever played and I wouldn't say that it is hard in a fair way which is unfortunate for this game and is its only real major downfall. It is hard for no other reason whatsoever other than it floods you with enemies and your guy can quite literally only take a slight few bullets then lights out. Two or three bullet hits puts you in red-screen heartbeat mode then one or two more hits and you are dead. Possibly the worst are snipers that can kill you in two shots and their sniper rifles can fire about 4 times a second. You can barely pop out of cover to shoot them so good luck with that. No single cover spot in the game is safe: you will get killed by a grenade shot or aliens will run up to you with super speed and use a melee stun move and you will get shot to death in two seconds or less while you are stunned. So far the first two boss fights are among some of the worst I have ever seen. They are not fun in any way, just getting a boss' life down low then dying over and over and over again is not fun. Enemy weapons fire a near constant laser stream of bullets at you and can even destroy your cover leaving you exposed. Another major downfall of the game: it punishes you incredibly hard when you die, making you replay large sessions, killing dozens of aliens over again. You can be doing really well, clearing an area of a swarm of aliens that takes what feels like an eternity, then one alien can just inexplicably finish you off or take you out entirely on his own, forcing you to redo a ♥♥♥♥ load of work by way of respawn at often poorly placed checkpoints. Being extremely difficult for the wrong reasons aside, this game gave me some fun times, however much so that now that it is over it is uninstalled and will never be played again. reviewText:
If Bulletstorm and Breed (remember that one?) had a disadvantaged baby, this would be their spawn.

Alien Rage is about as linear a FPS you can get, even including a useless jump ability that makes you wonder why they bothered with the effort to implement it.  There are objective markers leading you from one section to the next, but there really isn't a reason for it because you have no other direction to go. The weapons are few and lackluster. The enemies are few and lackluster.  The environments look the same until the very last levels (and even then, ... they look the same).

It is a skill-based FPS, where you are meant to rack up points by streaking head shots and by getting 10,20, 30, (and so on) special kills using secondary fire or explosions with the many, many explosive things to shoot at that the enemies conveniently take cover near.  There is a points (xp) based perk system tacked on.

Also, your bullets from different weapons do take time to travel a distance (so you have to lead on moving targets), and even have a little bit of a drop the further they go.

The story is actually pretty good, and there were some moments in the game that made me laugh.  The audio logs are hidden in plain sight, but blend with the environment so are easy to miss.

Overall the game is very fun.  Enemies rarely spawn behind you, are easy to kill, and if you plot an escape route with each battle, you can make a mess of the idiot aliens.  If you like being an ultimate bad-♥♥♥, this game is for you.  Just don't plan to be one in multiplayer.  No one is playing.

reviewText:
Quick Summary: Fast paced First Person Shooter with regenerating health (so you can charge in like a badass) and semi destructible environments. You can choose to replay chapters as you want in order to get higher scores and unlock “perks” which are passive bonuses such as increased health or damage.

You play a kind of space marine sent in alone to investigate what has happened on the asteroid Deimos, a “promethium” mine. Deimos happens to be the site of first contact with an alien race called the Vorus who are also very interested in the promethium. Everything was going well for a long time, so a sudden Vorus attack caught everyone off guard, and it’s up to you and your 2 teammates (a computer AI and a shuttle pilot) to get to the bottom of it while blasting the hordes of Vorus guarding the mines.

I mentioned that you have teammates on your mission, but they don’t actually help you in the game. Instead they serve as support, telling you which direction to go and giving you someone to talk to/banter with throughout the 8 hour game. There are 3 difficulties to choose from: Challenging, Hard, and Brutal. I chose Hard as my first runthrough, thinking that it was the equivalent of “medium” but I was wrong. Hard mode can be extremely difficult because you have no clear “advantage” over your enemies. They have access to the same guns you do, including the “secondary attack” of each weapon, which most of the time is some kind of underslung grenade/rocket launcher that can kill you in one shot (and they use them A LOT). The first couple of bosses are especially frustrating because they use chainguns that can tear apart whatever you’re taking cover behind (not giving you a chance to regenerate). The later bosses are actually much easier to beat (maybe because I unlocked some decent perks by then).

As for the weapon variety, there’s actually quite a bit to choose from, and they all have a different secondary attack. Personally I found the Vorus guns to be more useful since they don’t need to reload (just cool off once in a while). The player “perks” that I mentioned earlier are unlocked in tiers as you progress through the game, earning as many points as possible with special kill types (headshots, environmental kills, melee streaks, etc). I suspect you earn points faster on Hard difficulty because I unlocked all tiers of perks about halfway through the game. You can only equip 3 at one time though, so I focused on defensive perks. You really don’t have a lot of life on Hard difficulty.

Pros:
+Nice graphics and action packed gameplay. Like Halo or any other modern shooter for that matter, you can pick up just about any gun dropped by fallen enemies and just run/gun through the levels. No need to play it too safe scrounging for ammo or health kits (your health regens automatically).
+The game’s plot is told in “audio logs” that you find throughout the game and adds some nice backstory. The situation on Deimos really isn’t what it seems from first glance.
+There are a number of giant alien bosses to fight with your arsenal of guns.

Cons:
-Multiplayer is dead. It’s not too surprising since this isn’t a very well-known game and there’s no co-op gameplay.
-The Steam achievements are bugged. Some of them refuse to unlock and may require multiple playthroughs. For example, I’ve played through the game twice and haven’t gotten the “find every weapon” achievement even though I’ve unlocked the “kill an enemy with every weapon” achievement pretty early.

Overall, I’d say Alien Rage is closer in gameplay to Bulletstorm than anything else, but without the constant vulgarity, and with much less humor.

reviewText: The story is a self aware 80's action sci-fi film, the dialogue between characters is pretty funny and the level design is a bunch of narrow corridors but the level architecture (especially dem backgrounds) is very pretty. The game sells itself as an old-school shooter but I'm sure what they meant with that is that they tried to design a modern shooter with Nintendo Hard difficulty: you have a two weapon limit and a pistol with unlimited ammo, you have regenerating health that you recuperate by, you guessed it, hiding behind cover, every enemy is basically a terrorist who shoots a gun but with an alien model instead. The gameplay is very fast paced and every time you enter a room enemies will spawn in and you have to shoot them all then proceed. It's almost identical to Bulletstorm which was also made with Unreal Engine 3.\nIt would be an otherwise acceptable budget shooter if it weren't for the aforementioned difficulty: you have a very tiny health pool and you can even die in one shot from enemy attacks if you're unlucky enough. Taking cover behind objects is also a matter of luck since enemy explosive attacks (rockets) cause splash damage even if you're hiding behind object and can kill you outright while you're sitting still behind cover waiting for your health to regenerate. If the player health were increased and  splash damage were removed this would be an acceptable game if you're a fan of the genre, but as of right now it feels like it's trying very hard to extend what would otherwise be a 3 hour campaign by killing you over and over. There's better and genuinely good pure action shooters on Steam: Serious Sam 1 and 3, the Shadow Warrior Reboot, Bulletstorm, Hard Reset, the Rise of the Triad  remake and the first Painkiller. Only buy this if you've played all of the above and still really want another game with slightly similar gameplay.

reviewText:
Alien Rage is sci-fi first person shooter that will probably only appeal to masochists.

The game simply isn't much fun to play unfortunately.
The first problem is the poor optimisation, regardless of settings there are frame rate drops all over the place.
It turns out if you install a third party program and turn Texture Streaming off in the .ini file it runs a lot smoother (for the most part) but why should people have to do that?

Secondly the game isn't balanced at all.
A game can be difficult without being unfair, this game isn't though.
Enemies are bullet sponges (especially the bosses) and you can take very little damage before you die.
It doesn't help that checkpoints can often be quite far apart and cover is very hit and miss sometimes.
And you will need to use cover, again because of how little damage you can take but also because your health takes forever to recharge.
One section in particular stood out where two snipers (who can kill you in about two hits) were on a walkway in the distance firing there at least 1 shot a second rifles at me with nigh perfect accuracy.
The encounter boiled down to strafing out of cover, firing a couple of quick shots and hoping they hit (most weapons are about as accurate as a horoscope) and ducking back in before you're torn to shreds.
It wasn't fun or interesting or engaging, just tedious.

Some people might enjoy the difficulty, I just found it frustrating.

The third problem is it's really buggy.
In one area I fought a ton of enemies and reached a checkpoint then died in the next room. When I restarted the checkpoint the enemies from before had respawned, despite the fact them dying is what gave me the checkpoint in the first place. My only option then was to run back to a previous area and hope I didn't die in the process.

Another area had me shoot a switch to make a bridge appear but the middle was missing. I assumed I needed to do a running jump or find another switch or something but no, the bridge just didn't work for no reason.
It was only after dying in that area five times that the bridge decided to work as intended.
If this were some kind of physics based game I could maybe understand but it's not.

There are a ton of these kind of things, most recently a boss fight where the exploding tanks you use to injure the boss weren't shootable. They were visible on screen but mine and the enemies bullets just passed right through them.
There's no rhyme or reason to these things either, it's pure luck when you reload a checkpoint whether something will work as it's supposed to or not.

Mechanically some of the guns are fun to use and when you fix the texture streaming issue the game looks nice and runs quite well.
The story is little more than an excuse plot (at least at the point I'm at, about half way through the game) and the characters are all entirely unlikeable.

For the right price some people will probably really like this but I can't recommend it I'm afraid.

reviewText:
Quick Summary: Fast paced First Person Shooter with regenerating health (so you can charge in like a badass) and semi destructible environments. You can choose to replay chapters as you want in order to get higher scores and unlock “perks” which are passive bonuses such as increased health or damage.

You play a kind of space marine sent in alone to investigate what has happened on the asteroid Deimos, a “promethium” mine. Deimos happens to be the site of first contact with an alien race called the Vorus who are also very interested in the promethium. Everything was going well for a long time, so a sudden Vorus attack caught everyone off guard, and it’s up to you and your 2 teammates (a computer AI and a shuttle pilot) to get to the bottom of it while blasting the hordes of Vorus guarding the mines.

I mentioned that you have teammates on your mission, but they don’t actually help you in the game. Instead they serve as support, telling you which direction to go and giving you someone to talk to/banter with throughout the 8 hour game. There are 3 difficulties to choose from: Challenging, Hard, and Brutal. I chose Hard as my first runthrough, thinking that it was the equivalent of “medium” but I was wrong. Hard mode can be extremely difficult because you have no clear “advantage” over your enemies. They have access to the same guns you do, including the “secondary attack” of each weapon, which most of the time is some kind of underslung grenade/rocket launcher that can kill you in one shot (and they use them A LOT). The first couple of bosses are especially frustrating because they use chainguns that can tear apart whatever you’re taking cover behind (not giving you a chance to regenerate). The later bosses are actually much easier to beat (maybe because I unlocked some decent perks by then).

As for the weapon variety, there’s actually quite a bit to choose from, and they all have a different secondary attack. Personally I found the Vorus guns to be more useful since they don’t need to reload (just cool off once in a while). The player “perks” that I mentioned earlier are unlocked in tiers as you progress through the game, earning as many points as possible with special kill types (headshots, environmental kills, melee streaks, etc). I suspect you earn points faster on Hard difficulty because I unlocked all tiers of perks about halfway through the game. You can only equip 3 at one time though, so I focused on defensive perks. You really don’t have a lot of life on Hard difficulty.

Pros:
+Nice graphics and action packed gameplay. Like Halo or any other modern shooter for that matter, you can pick up just about any gun dropped by fallen enemies and just run/gun through the levels. No need to play it too safe scrounging for ammo or health kits (your health regens automatically).
+The game’s plot is told in “audio logs” that you find throughout the game and adds some nice backstory. The situation on Deimos really isn’t what it seems from first glance.
+There are a number of giant alien bosses to fight with your arsenal of guns.

Cons:
-Multiplayer is dead. It’s not too surprising since this isn’t a very well-known game and there’s no co-op gameplay.
-The Steam achievements are bugged. Some of them refuse to unlock and may require multiple playthroughs. For example, I’ve played through the game twice and haven’t gotten the “find every weapon” achievement even though I’ve unlocked the “kill an enemy with every weapon” achievement pretty early.

Overall, I’d say Alien Rage is closer in gameplay to Bulletstorm than anything else, but without the constant vulgarity, and with much less humor.

reviewText:
Alien Rage - Unlimited is a fast paced 1st person shooter that blends oldschool mechanics with modern elements of the genre.
A rather good story presents the conflict over promethium, a very rare resource, that involves the humans and an alien race called Vorus. At first, the two races seem to get along and share a giant meteor where promethium was found in abundance, but later the Vorus decide they want it all for themselves. You play as a badass marine that is sent to wipe out the aliens and stop any mining operations on that meteor. Parts of the story are told later on with the help of audio logs that you can find as collectibles and a more sinister plan is unveiled half-way through the game.

Level design is liniar, made up mostly of corridors connecting rooms and larger spaces for the boss encounters. In general, the action takes place inside the meteor's mining facilities and structures, with very rare moments when you go outside and get to admire the great sci-fi scenery. There is a turret ride and another level where you get to shoot things from inside an alien mech. Except for these, you can roam freely between checkpoints without many cut-scenes to bother. I also found some minor bugs, but nothing game-breaking.

Gameplay is very fast because many enemies will rush on your position. Tactical play is not impossible, but most of the time it is a run and gun scenario. Killing aliens is rewarded with points and badges pop-up at the top of the screen for certain actions (double-kill, explosive-kill, etc.). There is also a perk system that will unlock bonuses once you scored enough points. Aliens come in different types, from fast flankers to heavy armour, so you need to adapt and use weapons from both races. Guns feel great as aliens tend to melt under fire. I favored the energy weapons, but there is a weapon suited for every situation. Boss battles are brutal and you can die very fast if you don't stay in cover. Learn the specific mechanic for each boss and strike at the right time to succeed.

Takes about 8-9 hours to finish the campaign and you will die a lot. Fans of the FPS genre should not miss out on this game.

reviewText:
When I saw this game on Steam I felt it was going to be a nice purchase, but when I saw some reviews and metacritic’s final score, I thought something must be wrong, this game can’t be that bad to get a score of 52, so I bought it on a sale just to be sure I would not spend that much money on a possible bad game… Oh, boy… this game is a mixed bag and it tends to have more cons that pros in the end.

Story
The storyline is straightforward and simple, there are not complicated background stories nor characters and to be honest, its story is not the main protagonist here, it is just bland and lack originality. In the far future Humanity has reached the stars in search of new energies, earth’s natural resources are almost depleted and we need a solution, it happens we found an asteroid full of some new energy called Promethium, but we are not the only ones, another species called Vorus has also reached this asteroid in search of this new energy, so both races start jointly to exploit the mineral, everything was good for a time until the Vorus turn on the human miners and wipe them out. So Jack, our main protagonist, is sent to investigate the situation, kill the Vorus and destroy the facility.

Gameplay
The game is just a linear, first person shooter with zero variation, kill all enemies, go to the next stage, kill all enemies again, find mini-boss or first boss, end stage, next. Most levels look the same, they are mostly a corridor, except for when you reach certain larger areas to find enemies coming from multiple points. According to the game info on Steam, gameplay offers a cover mechanics to help you stand your ground over waves and waves of enemies, though, this apparently does not work or simply doesn’t exist, anyway, the gameplay is difficult, especially on hard and insane difficulties, so be prepare to die many times. Alien Rage has a scoring system, depending on the way you kill your enemies you are rewarded with medals, multi kills and blast master badges, among many others.

Enemies are not that varied, but they are fast and hard to kill at times, or just spawn in multiple waves over and over again, they also tend to blend with the stage’s environment, making it hard to see sometimes, in other occasions, they will just get you from behind or simply flank you, this tends to happen when you are being crowded, enemies also count with spawn options they have scattered all over the place. Weapons are not that varied either, and some of them are just useless or slow to use because you will usually have long distance fights by trying to use the “cover system” to your advantage, fortunately the secondary firing option of some weapons cause a lot damage and give you a break from the multiple enemies waves. Overall, gameplay is monotonous and it doesn’t offer more than what you can see on a gameplay or in-game images. So don’t expect anything out of the ordinary, Alien Rage is a simple, dull FPS.

Graphics
Alien Rage uses Unreal Engine 3, it looks good in game, flashy and shiny, some aspects of the limited access we have to the level’s environments are detailed, while some others show some muddy graphics, at times we encounter multiple layers of textures not loading properly, as most levels look the same and the lack of variations is patent, there is not much to add here, Unreal Engine shows off at key moments if we consider the amount of explosions that look great, the chaos we can create demonstrate the power of the engine regarding physics.

Sound and voices
The in game sounds and effects are decent, not groundbreaking, but they do their job, explosions and weapon effect sound exactly as you may expect from a game like this, nothing new, but they fit the concept here.

As for the voice acting, yeah, they are ok, main protagonist sounds always overly heroic and he tends to sound like a typical pseudo action man, annoying at times, yes, but I guess the voice acting fits the concept as well, the other two main acting voices exist only to give you instructions and deliver a quota of relief, with bad jokes and some sort of internal issue between them, they are just there doing their job with minor help.

The Bad
Where to begin? Alien Rage is filled with gameplay issues and graphical problems, starting with the mechanics of the game, there is no cover system to begin with, extremely necessary for a game that is relentless with many waves of enemies, AI is totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, Vorus just run towards you shooting nonstop waiting to be killed, The main character is very limited in movement, he is slow, big and clunky, sometimes during combat, the same stage is a total mess with explosions, bullets from every direction while you desperately look for a decent cover while trying to see where fire is coming from, multiple enemies that blend with the environment make the gameplay a continuous disaster regarding mechanics, I rather wait in a corner for the enemies to come to me so I can kill them one by one.

Graphical problems are constant here, textures not loading, muddy details, monotonous levels and stages, overly glossy elements invisible walls, of course there are invisible walls, the game is linear as hell, so you have a certain pattern to follow. Usually the textures don’t load properly every time you enter a new level or when you load a last save, showing the engine’s known issues.

Checkpoints are terrible, they constantly let you in the middle of enemy fire, you die, you load last save and again, multiple enemies surround you so you die again unless you act quickly enough to find some corner where to hide and recover or use the “cover system” to save your skin, again, the game has a terrible balance between you and your enemies, it is hard, I understand the crying over the difficulty is not an option, but handicapping you is also a problem when it comes to running or jumping, the latter is nonexistent, why the jumping mechanics are so messed up? I don’t really know, so you better bind the default space bar to another more functional action.

When it comes to boss battles, things are equally terrible, most of them are just bullet sponges that do a lot of damage and the lack of a proper cover system will only give you one option, which is running from one place to another trying to avoid enemy fire or whatever the attack is, they have weak spots so you have chances to beat them, running out of ammo will be always present in those moments, so you better shoot correctly. Some bosses will glitch-out at times, it happened in my play through a couple of times, these battles are not that challenging, but they tend to be monotonous and boring.

Conclusion
Alien Rage is a terrible decent game, it doesn’t offer original ideas or storyline, nor is any character worth remembering, which are not that many anyway, but if you want a challenge, a difficult one that will lead you to rage, this game is for you, other than that, you will be disappointed since the beginning. In my opinion, this game barely makes it to get a thumbs up, but as there is no neutral option between good and bad, I tried to be explicit regarding the bad side of it.

For when you want some meathead action and nothing more. Great graphics, really hard and good shooting, okay writing that is aware of its meathead genre and has fun with it. You play a Warhammer 40k-esque space marine who has so much armor that he can barely jump half a foot, and he's on a one-man-mission to do something or another that involves killing a bunch of aliens. The plot may or may not basically be Quake 2's plot (last-ditch attempt to stop invading alien marauders by taking the war to their homeworld), but after taking a break for a year I've completely forgotten whatever is supposed to be going on.

Which is fine, because who cares why I'm doing the things I do. The enemies are extremely fast and fairly powerful, the guns you get are really powerful and kind of samey, and there is a scoring system that encourages you to improvise and go nuts deep into every encounter. It's like a combination of Bulletstorm and Quake 4, but less ambitious than either of those. Less great level design, less interesting set pieces, but not exactly bad either. The levels are gorgeous in terms of their architecture and the vistas they present, but the layouts aren't anywhere near as interesting or clever. On the other hand, the encounters (how the enemies show up, which ones show up, where they show up, and the timing between their spawns) are consistently excellent, and every firefight feels like you're clawing your way out of hell.

And the game is ♥♥♥♥ing difficult. I'm playing on hard and need to take a break every thirty minutes from the sheer stress of it all, which is great. I get my shooting out the way and can play another walking simulator. It's like all that domestic fantasy ♥♥♥♥ Blazkowicz was mumbling about in the new Wolfenstein game, except now I'm mumbling it. It's the horror of war for the everyman.

Fix society: play Alien Rage.

reviewText:
Score - 65/100
Recommendation - Solid old-school shooter. Fans of Hard Reset rejoice.

This game was quite the surprise for me. I've become rather tough on games in recent years, and I can't even count the number of games I've played this year that I gave up on out of frustration. I tend to have an extremely short fuse when it comes to gameplay mechanics, but I enjoyed this one almost the whole way through.

I'll get this out of the way up front, though. There are some frustrating fights, you will likely die a LOT (even on the so-called normal difficulty), and the weapon choice is severely limited (ie some are entirely useless).

This game hails from the Serious Sam school, where games are almost perfectly linear, and waves of enemies spawn at pre-determined points for pre-determined lengths of time. Unlike Serious Sam, however, this game is short enough that the gimmick doesn't wear out its welcome. I ended up beating Alien Rage in about 6 hours, which I think is just perfect for this kind of mindless action. It seemed like the final level of Serious Sam 3 alone stretched out that long.

The graphics and sounds of Alien Rage fit their purpose as well. The music and sound are nothing to write home about, but the graphics are actually surprisingly nice. There were more than a few points where I simply stopped to admire the scenery. In addition, it's hard not to have a smile on your face while you're running around blasting alien creatures, bits and pieces of them flying around the screen. Such fights are somewhat rare, however, since you will be blasted full of more holes than a cheesecloth if you stay in the open for very long.

Speaking of battles, the boss fights are unfortunately quite poorly-done. There will be early ones where you will die over and over and over and over, and be millimeters from clicking on delete local content
date:
and then there will be later fights where you get a chaingun immediately before (and I do mean IMMEDIATELY), and demolish the boss in a matter of 30 seconds without even having to move. I had far more difficulty with the recharging boss than every other boss combined. Including the final one.

There are a wide variety of level types on tap as well. There are rail shooting levels, mech suit levels, and one style of level where the lights are mostly out and your gun emits a small scanner which illuminates cloaked enemies.

This game will inevitably be compared to Hard Reset, and while the two are quite similar, Alien Rage outshines it in a number of areas. First of all, you can jump in this game, and while that is never EVER actually needed, it makes the movement feel much less stuffy. In addition, the story and acting in Alien Rage are really quite well done. Where Hard Reset's story felt ridiculous, poorly-acted, and peppered with lame attempts at humor, Alien Rage's story is actually complex, engaging, well-acted, and somewhat humorous. It's worth mentioning that Alien Rage's story is almost entirely told through audio logs which can be missed, but I mean it when I say the game is linear; it would be hard to miss too many logs. I didn't look too close, and ended up with 29/33. It's also worth mentioning that there are a LOT of pop culture references. I found them funny, but I know how those annoy some people.

Overall, if you enjoyed Hard Reset (or other oldschool-ish games), you will enjoy this too. It's difficult, fast-paced, bright and shiny, the AI is dumb, and it keeps track of high scores for the competitive folks out there. It has multiplayer too, but I didn't try it. I have a feeling it's just deathmatch.

I recommend picking it up. I can't honestly say I would have happily spent more than $10 on it, but I am notoriously cheap. :)

-DrB

reviewText:
This game might be biggest pile of bugs i've have ever seen during my years ( long years ) of gaming.

First of all this is made on Unreal engine 4 i believe (sorry if im wrong) . Engine we all know and love , yet  somehow this game will run like poop no matter how expensive your rig is. There are ways around it , tweaking .INI file will solve all performance issues this game has but to make game which runs so bad on such a good and trusted engine is a sin.

Alien rage was first game in 15 years which literally made me sick. I know that people who suffer from motion sickness have issues with certain games making them feel dizzy and giving them headaches. I've never been on that unlucky side. Thou this game managed to almost make me vomit with it's ridiculous motion blur ( which cant be turned off in menu's ) and vomit inducing FX effects . Gladly , again , you can turn them off if you edit .INI file.

Every time you die , and you will die a lot 'cause game is pretty hard , you get your standar 'restart from last checkpoint' option . What's different from other games is that then you do that half of level wont load . Doors wont trigger open , enemies will be invincible,parts you have to interact with wont be interactable. One must go back to main menu and then load last save again. Keeping in mind that game is hard, you will have to do this a lot which sucks joy out of you.

And the worst thing about this game is that.... it's a good game. Game of genre we rarely see these days , old school FPS . Only titles in recent memory which managed to capture this feeling was Hard Reset,Bullet Storm and new Wolfenstein . That's it....and i can add Alien Rage to this small small list now. It's very solid in terms of mechanics, shooting is fun, guns awesome , it requires a lot of skill . No hand helding here. I like it...and i hate how dev's utterly failed to make this game actually playable.

This could have been GREAT GAME.

reviewText:
This isn't the game for everyone, less-so for Halo or Gears or War fans. But it's a fantastic strategic-shooter, in the sense that you really have to try different strategies for each area not to die.
The plot and dialogue are better than both Halo and Bulletstorm, both of which it has some cultural ancestry through. And yes, it is a little derivative of Halo in terms of the weapon system, but then, Halo was derivative of virtually everything.
I wouldn't advise any difficulty level other than 'Challenging' - you're really not going to enjoy the game otherwise. But played right, this is reminiscent of the difficulty of Serious Sam 1 on 'Hard' mode, trying to desperately think of a way to not die and go back to your savegame.

The visuals, though perplexing and detailed at first, quickly become navigable, and in time you'll come to appreciate how polished this game is, both in textural and structural details.

Sound-wise - pretty good, pretty standard, though some nice touches here and there.
And I actually found the boss fights pretty satisfying and enervating - a great combination of 'figure out the strategy' and adrenaline-fueled desperation and chasing.

If you never played an old-school FPS, get used to the following tactics -
1. Cover is not always going to stay upright, or be perfect at blocking explosions and bullets, depending on how wide it is and where you're placed.
2. Retreat to better tactical location is always an option, and usually necessary.
3. Fast reflexes and headshots win wars.

Overall a very satisfying experience, and no-way-near worth the ire it's attracted. Again, not everybody's game - but then, why would it be? And what's wrong with another game that's not as simple or puerile as GoW clones?

Alien Rage is a no-nonsense sci-fi FPS.  The lone, badaas, spacemarine VS an entire planet full of alien goons reminded me of Quake 2, in a good way.  Effects and animations are great.  Collectables and unlockable perks to encourage exploration and add replay value.

The environments don't show much variation on the theme of steel hallways.  While there are several weapon types the environments really only favor a few of them and we only get to use the pilotable mech on one level, it seems a waste.

The Unreal engine does a solid job of holding keeping the game together I did enounter a few gameplay glitches which kind of broke the immersion from time to time.

Overall I can still thourougly recommend this game for a mindless shoot-em up.

reviewText: Alien Rage - Unlimited is a great game, a very atmospheric and highly underrated FPS, which bears all the traits of old school shooters of the 90s, which means; its freaking hard even on the second difficulty setting and the bosses are a real challenge (i.e.: The boss at the end of Level 2 was already very hard to beat. If I should sum up the three difficulties you can find ingame; Very Hard, Insane and ♥♥♥♥ You.). The game has an interesting storyline, good characters and voice acting (As good as in a sci-fi FPS they can be.). You may also hear plenty great references to other classics. The weapons have real power, the generic grunt enemies are also a challenge (Meaning they can kill you with a few shots, even the very first ones you'll encounter with in game.), and the entire setting looks great and well crafted, special thanks to Unreal 3. The world of Alien Rage reminds me mostly for the mix of Gears of War, Halo, Bulletstorm and Quake 2, with the hard core and challenging gameplay of the original Doom, Quake and Wolfenstein series. The game is very long, comparing the other games in the genre (It took about 11 hours to beat all 14 levels.). Alien Rage is a very nice fast paced FPS which is very satisfying and reminds me for the shooters of the glorious 1990s, and it is highly recommended for those who love a real challenge.

reviewText:
Well this game has rly mixed reviews on the Internet, and I wanted to find out why. At 1st it looks like an oldschool shooter with an awesome sci-fi setting but as soon as you start playing you realize that it's more like Duke Nukem Forever. Mixing Old and New stuff but not doing a rly good job with it.

Graphics:  So the game looks quite nice. However the textures are low res. Sometimes I felt like playing Darsiders II because the game has rly cool aesthetics but the tech is inferior. It runs fairly good on my PC tho there are some places when I felt some FPS drop. The other problem is the variety. You are in a spacestation, a mining facily, an alien mothership, labs....and all of them look the same! Thats a rly big problem with the game. These should have been different from each other in aesthetic wise.

Sound:  The game uses many public domain sounds but in a good way. Every sound effect sounds right and nothing feels out of it's place. The weapon sounds are punchy too. The voice acting is nice especially the announcer who sounds almost exactly like Don LaFontaine. The dialogs are funny and cheesy but in a good way. I had some smiles listening them. The music is okay.

Gameplay:  So I mentioned DNF at the begining now I tell you why. You have a weapon limit system of 3. The 1st one is the always the same backup pistol and 2 other weapons you can pick up. This means you have basically 2 weapons and a pistol. There are alien and human wariations of the same weapon which is cool but they are basically the same. You can also pick up a minigun but it's basically a carry weapon which means you have to drop it if you wanna use any of your other weapons. Another problem is the regenerating health. I've found myself in cover almost every time I had a fight. And sitting behind chest high walls waiting for my health to regenerate is not fun. And the game is difficult. I died many times on the middle difficulty  (Normal, Hard, Brutal). You can get scores from kills, bonuses and other destructive stuff just like in Bulletstorm. If you have enough points you can unlock perks. These perks can add more firepower, defense, or other bonuses for you. This is a nice little feature but nothing special. However the last perk is cool.
There are collectibles like Bonus points and Audio logs, but these are not rly well hidden because of the extremely linear level design. Seriously you are always walking in 1 lane. Sometimes 2 but thats extreme stuff.

Replayability:  You can earn achievements for multiple playthroughs but I think the game is not that great. If it had more variety in aesthetics and level design I would recommend it but in this case it's just a one time run. And it lasts 7,8 hours if you are exploring the levels for hidden stuff.

Overall:   Pros:
Voice acting
Nice grapics, tho low rez textures
Funny, cheesy dialoges
Nice animations
Sci-fi aesthetics (which gets boring after 3 hours)
Music is okay Cons:
Weapon limit
Health regen
Alt fire uses shared ammo and not rly differs from each other
Sometimes unfair spawns
DOF and Motion Blur, however they are used in a less irritating way
One of the most annoying flashlights of all time
Invisible walls, linear level design
All cover, no man
Alien grenade launchers...those things...
Unskippable cutscenes and checkpoints before them...
No autosave or any kind of save feature outside of the checkpoint system
I died while I was watching a cutscene... very irritating cuz you can't do anything
Your weapons shoots everywhere without ADS (seriously get rit of ADS is this kind of games)
Your jump is almost non existent.
No vertical gameplay
Verdict:  This is a mediocre game but has some cool ideas and funny moments. It's not bad but not great either. If you have some time and you liked DNF you are problably going to like this one. I had some good moment and some bad. I'm not recomendig this at full price. I think City Interactive needs good game designers because I can see the talent there but somethings gets in their way every time they want to create a good game.

reviewText:
Great shoot 'em up game with gorgeous visuals  that poses no real difficulty in the comprehension of the story, as the story is almost 'optional' in my opinion and I will explain why.

Throughout the game, little audio files are scattered in various locations that give chronological order to the charade of events that occured prior.  They are depicted as collectibles, roughly 3 to be found on each map. If you play it and walk away, you won't be able to hear it. If you play it and get attacked by aliens then you won't be able to hear it. Thus it is like a little extra add on to the game, much like the bonus collectibles.

Despite this, the games visuals blew me away, the difficulty was spot on and the game is over all, intense! The environment starts to all look the same after a while but nonetheless, it  looks absolutely stunning. I'd never heard of this game before seeing it in an inexpensive bundle so understandably, my expectations weren't too high.

The boss' in the game do pose a bit more of a challenge which I appreciate. Each boss is normally just the same as the last boss but with an addon function, say a jetpack or a minigun ect. Although, they create a unique experience and it doesn't feel repetitive and is overall a  good experience.

If you're a gamer who likes a good story with your FPS chaos then I would recommend to give this one a miss, but if you're just looking to enjoy shooting things with nice scenery then I would definitely say to give it a try.
